_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Camuy-Hatillo Wastewater Treatment Plant is located at the State Road 485 Km 3.5 Bo. Membrillo Sector Bajura Camuy, Puerto Rico, 000627.  This water treatment plant  is owned by Puerto Rico Aqueduct and Sewer Authority (PRASA) which is a Government Agency.  PRASA has developed the RMP following the Program #3 for the Management and Prevention of Risks associated with the storage and handling of the toxic substance used as for water disinfection: Chlorine.  The RMP was prepared in compliance with EPA 40 CFR Part68.  The Prevention Program was prepared in accordance with OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation, as established in 29 CFR Part 1910.119.



Accidental Release:

It is PRASA policy to comply with EPA and OSHA Federal and State applicable requirements. Chlorine is a toxic substance regulated by EPA, for that reason Camuy-Hatillo Wastewater Treatment Plant is observing the appropriated engineering controls.  Changes have been put in place to improve safety and as a part of the Prevention Plan implanted to protect the wellness of workers, employees, contractors, visitors and immediately surrounding areas and inhabitants.



The Stationary Source and Regulated Substance handled.

Camuy-Hatillo Wastewater Treatment Plant is located close to the Atlantic Ocean where the plant discharges the treated water.  The chlorine is used as a disinfectant to destroy the microorganism that could cause illness in humans and contamination of the receiving water body.

The chlorine is delivered from San Juan Chlorine Warehouse and Distribution Center to the plant in one (1) ton containers.  Camuy-Hatillo Wastewater Treatment Plant could has a  maximum storage volume of 12,000 pounds distributed in six (6) containers.  Two containers are connected to chlorinators only one container is used at the time the chlorine flows to the vacuum dosificator and from it the chlorine is sent to the contact chamber, through a underground pipeline, where it is combined with the used wat

er at the end of plants process.



Worst Case Scenario:

The Worst Case Scenario was determined as indicated in the EPA Wastewater Treatment Plant, as per Appendix F Supplemental Risk Management Program Guidance for Wastewater Treatment Plants.  This guidance considers the release of the Chlorine Gas of the entire container (2,000 pounds) during 10 minutes and other specifications related to the weather conditions and a radio of 1.3 miles, for a chlorine concentration equal or higher than 3 ppm, which is the American Industrial Hygiene Association exposure limit above which it is determined human health will be affected.  Using the Marplot EPA Simulator and the US Census 2010, it was identified that 4,603 public receptors are inside the 1.3 miles radio.  No known environmental receptors beside the beach (state parks, or official designated wildlife preserves) are located within this radio area.  The ALOHA Modeling Dispersion Program was used to simulate the gas dispersion.



Alternative Case Scenario:

The more realistic scenario was also simulated as per EPA Wastewater Treatment Plants parameters, as a release of the total content of a 2,000 pounds container, but throughout a 3/8 inch valve rupture.  In such case the end point distance is calculated as 0.1 miles and none public receptors were identified over the most modeling map.  Recent aerial photographs evaluated show some residences within the 0.1 radius and an estimate of 14 residents live in the area.  No known environmental receptors, besides the beach, are located within the radio area.



General Accident Release Prevention Program 

PRASA is actually in a very aggressive operation to implement a Prevention Plan to ensure the maintenance and mechanical integrity of the facility which will improve significantly the safety scope of the current prevention plans.  Standard Operational Procedures (SOPs) are already in place to comply the OSHA and PROSHO requirements in order to keep all the involved parties

aware of the hazardous and risk related to the chlorine.  List of all SOPs are indicated in the PSM report and are located in the plant.



Emergency Response Program:

PRASA has various SOPs to manage emergency programs associated to a release of the chlorine and also related to the emergency actions to be taken before and after hurricanes and other atmospherics events.



Five years Accident History:

No mayor release of chlorine in excess of ten (10) pounds has been reported during the last five years. 



Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

PRASA will implement in Camuy-Hatillo Wastewater Treatment Plant, practical training in the chlorine processes with all plant operators more frequently in order to improve safety practices  and create more confidence in the management of the chlorine processes.
